member.name: T:uGameDB.BitStream
member.summary: Represents serialized variables, packed into a stream.
member.remarks:
Data can be serialized, transmitted, and then received by remote clients by using this class. Read about state synchronization and automatic serializations of data types in the uLink manual to get the big picture. The code for serializing and deserializing objects are usually placed in the callback method . Check out the C# and javascript code examples for that callback method.
Also see the two other callbacks that are used to serialize and desierialize objects in some special situations:
and .
We recommend that C# code and javascript code (also called Unity script) uses the methods and . Yes, it is possible to use generic types in javascript in Unity. It is not possible to use generic types in javascript outside Unity, this is a feature that has been added by Unity since v3.0 of the Editor.
Arrays (only one-dimentional) are handled by uLink. Arrays are no problem for methods like and
If you are using an Unity version older than 3.0, or for some other reason can't use generics, you can use the and methods.
There are several methods for reading and writing just one specific datatype. These can be used to gain some performance, but the code you have to write will usually be a bit longer and not as elegant. Two examples of these method pairs are / and /.
Because uLink is backward compatible with the Unity built-in network the method is included in this class and can still be used. It supports a limited set of basic datatypes (the same as Unity built-in network). The new method can be used to handle more data types (all data types supported by uLink), but we recommend that you use the generic read/write methods whenever possible.

member.name: F:uGameDB.BitStream.isTypeSafe
member.summary: Used to make this stream serialize the type of data types and check all data types when deserializing.
member.remarks: Set this value to true if you want extra validations when reading incoming data. This is good for debugging and it is also good for detecting clients sending wrong data to a server or vice versa. Be aware that the serialized data will become longer when the data types has to be stored.
member.exception: If expected data type does not match the data type in the stream when reading it.

member.name: T:uGameDB.NetworkFlags
member.summary: Used to control how RPCs will be handled by uLink.
member.remarks: Turn on one or many the these bit flags to make uLink handle the RPC exactly the way you want it. The buffer flag argument will overrule the buffer setting that the argument in the function usually controls. If they are conflicting, uLink log a warning.

member.name: F:uGameDB.NetworkFlags.Normal
member.summary: This is the base value. The RPC will be reliable, buffered, encrypted, typesafe and include a timestamp.

member.name: F:uGameDB.NetworkFlags.Unreliable
member.summary: The RPC is sent over an unreliable network channel in uLink. Default is OFF.

member.name: F:uGameDB.NetworkFlags.Unbuffered
member.summary: The RPC is not stored in the RPC buffer on the server. This flag overrules the buffer setting. Default Value is OFF.

member.name: F:uGameDB.NetworkFlags.Unencrypted
member.summary: The RPC is never encrypted, even if sequrity is turned on. Default value is OFF.

member.name: F:uGameDB.NetworkFlags.NoTimestamp
member.summary: The RPC has no timestamp (to save bandwidth). Default value is OFF.

member.name: F:uGameDB.NetworkFlags.TypeUnsafe
member.summary: The types of the arguments in the RPC will not be checked when this RPC is received. Default value is OFF.

member.name: F:uGameDB.NetworkStateSynchronization.Unreliable

member.name: T:uGameDB.NetworkLog
member.summary: Class for configuring uLink logging.
member.remarks:
The best way to get started with logging in uLink is to use the Editor menu: uLink - Edit Settings. There it is possbile to configure logging level per category and use the generated output to debug most problems. By default the log messages are written to the Unity console window in the editor or the log file output_log.txt when running a build outside the editor.
Use this class to go one step further and control the log settings in your own code. Also use it to replace the 4 public Writers with your own faster implementations: , , , with your own implementations it is possible to log events to screen or file(s) or database or whatever you like.
Finally, it is possible to add your own logging categories like “Trading”, “Cheating attempts” or “Level loding” and set the log level individually for these categories.

member.name: M:uGameDB.NetworkLog.Debug(uGameDB.NetworkLogFlags,System.Object[])
member.summary: Sends a log message to the delegate if the log level for the specifed categories (flags) are set by either or .
member.param: The categories this log message belongs to
The objects that are to be concatenated to a log message if the debug log level for the flags is set
member.example:
Example code for writing a message like "The server has now received 88 Fire RPCs from player Paul55".
uLink.NetworkLog.Debug(uLink.NetworkLogFlags.Server, "The server has now received ", numberOfFireRPCs, " Fire RPCs from player ", playerName);
member.remarks: Please note that it is important to NOT use string concatenation with + to compose the log message. Instead send the objects individually just like the example code provided here. Otherwise you will lose performace. The concatenation would be executed even if the log level for the flags are turned off, and that is a waste of CPU resources.

member.summary: Special value to indicate quorum, i. e. (N/2 + 1) replicas where N is the n_val set for the bucket. The numeric value equals 4294967295 - 2.

member.name: F:uGameDB.Constants.Replication.All
member.summary: Special value to indicate all replicas. The numeric value equals 4294967295 - 3.

member.name: F:uGameDB.Constants.Replication.Default

member.name: T:uGameDB.Request
member.summary: Base class for all the request classes.

member.name: M:uGameDB.Request.WaitUntilDone
member.summary: Use this function to wait for the request to complete, i.e. until Request.isDone is true, using the Unity coroutine mechanism. Typically you would call 'yield return request.WaitUntilDone();' from a coroutine before examining the result of the request. The coroutine will resume once any given success or error callback has finished, unless the request was cancelled by the user. Then the coroutine will resume without any callback being invoked.
member.returns: A Coroutine object that can be yielded on from a coroutine.

member.name: M:uGameDB.Request.Cancel
member.summary: Cancels a previously sent request, which removes it from the list of pending requests. Calling this will make Request.isDone true, which means that any coroutine which has yielded on Request.WaitUntilDone() will resume. Canceling a request will not trigger any of the callbacks.

member.name: M:uGameDB.Request.GetError
member.summary: Gets the error status of a failed request.
member.returns: The error status of the request.
member.remarks: If there is no error, this will throw a DatabaseRequestException. If you are unsure if the request has an error or not, you can avoid the exception by checking Request.hasFailed or by using Request.TryGetError().

member.name: T:uGameDB.Bucket
member.summary: A local handle to a Riak bucket, represented by its name. Use instances of this class to send requests to read and write data within one bucket. You can also use static members of this class to manipulate all buckets.

member.name: M:uGameDB.Bucket.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new local object with a given name. Note that this does not create a bucket in the database. A Riak bucket is only created when a write request is sent to write data into it. This means that you can create any number of instances of the Bucket class without any requests being sent.
member.param: The name of the Riak bucket.

member.name: M:uGameDB.Bucket.MapReduce(uGameDB.JavaScriptMapPhase,uGameDB.JavaScriptReducePhase,uGameDB.OnResponseCallback{uGameDB.MapReduceRequest},uGameDB.OnResponseCallback{uGameDB.MapReduceRequest})
member.summary: Sends a request to perform a MapReduce query operation on the Riak cluster. This variant of MapReduce uses JavaScript phase functions expressed as strings, which are sent along with the request. Its input will be every key in the bucket.
member.param: A object that contains the JavaScript code of the Map phase function to send along with the request.
A object that contains the JavaScript code of the Reduce phase function to send along with the request.
An optional callback that will be invoked if the request succeeds.
An optional callback that will be invoked if the request fails.
member.returns: A object that represents the request until it completes.
member.remarks: This is uGameDB's primary functionality for selecting one or more results from database based on an arbitrary criterion. A MapReduce request is divided into two phases. The Map phase is a function that takes one key/value pair as input and produces a list of intermediate results. The Reduce phase is a function that takes a list of such intermediate results as input and produces a new list of results. By default, the results of the Reduce phase is returned as the result of the MapReduce request. You can read more about MapReduce queries in the uGameDB manual.

member.name: M:uGameDB.Bucket.GetKeysByIndex(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Gets the keys of this bucket that have secondary index values within a given lexiographical range. Requires a Riak backend that supports secondary indexes, otherwise a Request rejected by Riak error will be reported by .
member.param: The name of the secondary index on which to perform the look up.
Inclusive lower bound index value of the search range.
Inclusive upper bound index value of the search range.
member.returns: A object that represents the request.
member.remarks: The range is specified with lower and upper inclusive bounds. For example, if the range is "b"-"z", "a" and "zz" will be outside of the range, but "b", "bb" and "z" will be inside the range. If the bounds are in the wrong order (upper smaller than lower), they are automatically re-ordered by the database. This is equivalent to calling GetKeysByIndex(index, indexValueLow, indexValueHigh, null, null);.

member.name: T:uGameDB.OnConnectCallback
member.summary: Used by Database.Connect() to describe a callback that is invoked when the uGameDB client is successfully brought online.

member.name: T:uGameDB.OnConnectFailureCallback
member.summary: Used by Database.Connect() to describe a callback that in invoked when an error prevents the uGameDB client to be brought online.
member.param: An error message that describes the reason why the client can't go online.

member.name: T:uGameDB.Database
member.summary: This is the class that houses all the global operations of uGameDB. Use it to connect, configure database nodes, retrieve connection status and information, etc.

member.name: M:uGameDB.Database.Connect(uGameDB.OnConnectCallback,uGameDB.OnConnectFailureCallback)
member.summary: This will set the uGameDB client to an online state, which means it will start connecting to all configured database nodes. The actual connections are made behind the scenes and depends on the number of requests that are sent and when. The method will not fail if one or more nodes are unavailable. In uGameDB's view, it is normal for database nodes to become unreachable for different reasons. If one node is not responding, uGameDB will silently try to send the request to another node instead. For this reason, the only time onErrorCallback is invoked is when an error occurs on the client that prevents it from entring the online state.
member.param: Invoked when the client successfully entered the online state. If this is null, nothing will happen.
Invoked if the client was prevented from entering the online state. If this is null, nothing will happen.

member.name: M:uGameDB.Database.Connect
member.summary: This will set the uGameDB client to an online state, which means it will start connecting to all configured database nodes. The actual connections are made behind the scenes and depends on the number of requests that are sent and when. The method will not fail if one or more nodes are unavailable. In uGameDB's view, it is normal for database nodes to become unreachable for different reasons. If one node is not responding, uGameDB will silently try to send the request to another node instead. For this reason, the only time onErrorCallback is invoked is when an error occurs on the client that prevents it from entring the online state.
member.remarks: This is equivalent to calling Connect(null, null), which means that no callbacks will be invoked.

member.name: M:uGameDB.Database.Disconnect
member.summary: This will set the uGameDB client to an offline state, which means it will stop all background connection attempts. This will also remove all pending and queued requests.

member.summary: Adds the specified database node and makes it available for future connections. After you call Database.AddNode() you need to call Database.Connect() for the new node it to be used. If the client is already online, you must call Database.Disconnect() followed by Database.Connect() for the new node to be used.
member.param: A user-specified name that identifies the configured node on the client.
The network address of the database node. Can be either a DNS name or an IP address.
The PBC port of the database node.
The maximum number of connections that can be simultaneously maintained by the client to this node.
The time, in milliseconds, that a connection will wait for a write operation to complete before the node is considered unavailable.
The time, in milliseconds, that a connection will wait for a read operation to complete before the node is considered unavailable.

member.name: M:uGameDB.Database.RemoveNode(System.String)
member.summary: Removes a previously configured database node from the client. After you call Database.RemoveNode(), you need to call Database.Connect() for the change to take effect. If the client is already online, you must call Database.Disconnect() followed by Database.Connect() for the change to take effect.
member.param: The user-specified name that was used in the call to Database.AddNode().

member.name: M:uGameDB.Database.RemoveAllNodes
member.summary: Removes all previously configured nodes from the client. After you call Database.RemoveAllNodes() you need to call Database.Connect() for the change to take effect. If the client is already online, you must call Database.Disconnect() followed by Database.Connect() for the change to take effect.

member.name: M:uGameDB.Database.MapReduceOnBucketKeyList(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{uGameDB.BucketKeyPair},uGameDB.JavaScriptMapPhase,uGameDB.JavaScriptReducePhase,uGameDB.OnResponseCallback{uGameDB.MapReduceOnBucketKeyListRequest},uGameDB.OnResponseCallback{uGameDB.MapReduceOnBucketKeyListRequest})
member.summary: Sends a request to perform a MapReduce query operation on the Riak cluster. This variant of MapReduce uses JavaScript phase functions expressed as strings, which are sent along with the request. Its input will be a given list of bucket and key pairs.
member.param: The list of instances that should be used as inputs to the Map phase.
A object that contains the JavaScript code of the Map phase function to send along with the request.
A object that contains the JavaScript code of the Reduce phase function to send along with the request.
An optional callback that will be invoked if the request succeeds.
An optional callback that will be invoked if the request fails.
member.returns: A object that represents the request until it completes.
member.remarks: This is uGameDB's primary functionality for selecting one or more results from database based on an arbitrary criterion. A MapReduce request is divided into two phases. The Map phase is a function that takes one key/value pair as input and produces a list of intermediate results. The Reduce phase is a function that takes a list of such intermediate results as input and produces a new list of results. By default, the results of the Reduce phase is returned as the result of the MapReduce request. You can read more about MapReduce queries in the uGameDB manual.

member.name: P:uGameDB.Database.isConnected
member.summary: Returns true if the uGameDB client is in a connected state. Note that this does not necessarily mean that it is connected to a database node and is able to serve requests. As nodes can go up and down, isConnected only says that uGameDB is actively trying to connect, and reconnect if necessary, to all configured database nodes.

member.name: P:uGameDB.Database.pendingRequestCount
member.summary: Returns the number of requests that are currently pending. A pending request is a request that has been submitted by the user, but that has not yet returned. A request is no longer pending when it has returned with either success or failure, when it times out, or when it has been cancelled by the user.

member.name: P:uGameDB.Database.queuedRequestCount
member.summary: Returns the number of requests that has been queued on the client, waiting to be sent over the network to a database node. This is usually a small value, unless a lot of requests are being sent from the client at once. If there is a constantly high or growing number of queued requests, you can try to increase the number of connections in the node configuration to be able to send more requests simultaneously.

member.name: P:uGameDB.Database.nodeCount
member.summary: Returns the total number of database nodes that has been configured on the uGameDB client. Use Database.onlineNodeCount to get the current number of nodes that are online.

member.name: P:uGameDB.Database.onlineNodeCount
member.summary: Returns the total number of online database nodes. While uGameDB is connected it regularly sends pings to every database node in order to track which ones that are available to serve requests.

member.name: P:uGameDB.Database.nodePingInterval
member.summary: This sets the time in milliseconds between each ping that are sent to nodes to determine if they are online and available. Once you set it, you must call Database.Connect() in order for the new value to take effect.

member.name: P:uGameDB.Database.requestTimeout
member.summary: This sets the time in seconds that a request is allowed to wait for a response from the database, before it times out.

member.name: P:uGameDB.Database.useVectorClockCache
member.summary: Sets if uGameDB should use local vector clock caching on the client.
member.remarks: Vector clock caching stores the new vector clock (data version id) after each write so that it can be sent along with the next write to the same data entry. If caching is not used, uGameDB must begin each write request with fetching the data header for the entry from Riak and then use the obtained vector clock for the write. If caching is used uGameDB can use the cached vector clock and send the write request directly. Caching can increase performance in cases when it is unlikely that some other database client has written to the same entry, which makes the cached vector clock invalid. However, caching can degrade performance if the cached vector clocks often are outdated. The default is true.

member.name: T:uGameDB.Database.Debug
member.summary: Contains some additional database features that are useful for debugging purposes, but should never be used in production code.

member.name: M:uGameDB.Database.Debug.ResetGlobalState
member.summary: Resets the global state of the uGameDB client, putting it back into an initial state. This should not be used in producition code, but is good for testing purposes.

member.name: M:uGameDB.Database.Debug.SetSibling``1(uGameDB.Bucket,System.String,``0,uGameDB.Encoding)
member.summary: Sends a request to write the value under the given key to the database without supplying a vector clock. Repeated writes under the same key will simulate a collision in Riak, and if AllowMult is Allowed in the bucket, force the creation of a sibling. Should only be used for debugging.
member.typeparam: The type of the value. Usually this does not need to be explicitly specified but can be inferred from the type of the value parameter.
member.param: The bucket in which the value should be stored.
The key to associate with the value.
The value to write.
The encoding to use when serializing the value to the database.
member.returns: A object that represents the request until it completes.
member.remarks: If AllowMult is Allowed, a sibling will be created even if a tombstone resides under the key. This might cause inconsistencies when trying to deserialize the data. This is equivalent to calling SetSibling(bucket, key, value, encoding, null, Constants.WriteMode.Default, Constants.Replication.Default, Constants.Replication.Default, null, null);.

member.name: M:uGameDB.Database.Debug.SetSibling``1(uGameDB.Bucket,System.String,``0,uGameDB.Encoding,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{uGameDB.IndexEntry})
member.summary: Sends a request to write the value under the given key to the database without supplying a vector clock. Repeated writes under the same key will simulate a collision in Riak, and if AllowMult is Allowed in the bucket, force the creation of a sibling. Should only be used for debugging.
member.typeparam: The type of the value. Usually this does not need to be explicitly specified but can be inferred from the type of the value parameter.
member.param: The bucket in which the value should be stored.
The key to associate with the value.
The value to write.
The encoding to use when serializing the value to the database.
Secondary indexes to be stored together with the value. Must not be null for this overload.
member.returns: A object that represents the request until it completes.
member.remarks: If AllowMult is Allowed, a sibling will be created even if a tombstone resides under the key. This might cause inconsistencies when trying to deserialize the data. This is equivalent to calling SetSibling(bucket, key, value, encoding, indexes, Constants.WriteMode.Default, Constants.Replication.Default, Constants.Replication.Default, null, null);.

member.summary: Sends a request to write the value under the given key to the database without supplying a vector clock. Repeated writes under the same key will simulate a collision in Riak, and if AllowMult is Allowed in the bucket, force the creation of a sibling. Should only be used for debugging.
member.typeparam: The type of the value. Usually this does not need to be explicitly specified but can be inferred from the type of the value parameter.
member.param: The bucket in which the value should be stored.
The key to associate with the value.
The value to write.
The encoding to use when serializing the value to the database.
Optional secondary indexes to be stored together with the value. Pass null to ignore.
The mode to use when writing. Currently, the only supported mode is Overwrite.
The number of memory-written replicas to wait for before returning success.
The number of disk-written replicas to wait for before returning success.
An optional callback that will be invoked if the request succeeds.
An optional callback that will be invoked if the request fails.
